citations.narrative:
The facility’s Acquisition of Dogs on Hand (Form 7005) shows 42 adult dogs on hand. The inventory count obtained
during inspection is 13 adult dogs. The facility representative states that they have not made changes to the 7005 form
recently with recent dog dispositions. A correct inventory count is important to maintain for disease traceback, and in
cases of theft or loss. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose each dog
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of. Correct by maintaining current
and accurate inventory on all dogs at the facility.
To be corrected by: 18-November-2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Several primary enclosures housing 12 adult dogs have an excessive accumulation of hair and brown, dusty organic
debris coating the wires on top of the enclosures. Two of the corner enclosures have a heavy buildup of cobwebs above
them as well. Accumulation of dirt, hair, debris and cobwebs can serve as a source of disease hazards, which may cause
injury or illness to the dogs. Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures be cleaned and sanitized at least once every 2
weeks or as often as needed to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, or other disease hazards.
To be corrected by: 18-November-2024

The Program of Veterinary Care states the attending veterinarian will complete a site visit every 6 months. The attending
veterinarian has not been to the facility since 27-March-2024 and is now overdue for the site visit. Regularly scheduled
site visits are essential in determining if all aspects of animal care (nutrition, health, environment, water, and air quality,
etc.) are being provided to the dogs. The licensee must have regularly scheduled visits by the attending veterinarian to
the facility where animals are kept, to assess and ensure the adequacy of veterinary care and other aspects of animal
care and use.
To be corrected by: 27-November-2024

Six adult dogs did not have an a complete physical examination from head to tail by the attending veterinarian done every
12 months. The dogs not examined were Pomeranian #221, Pugs #165, #296, #282, Maltese #173 and Mini Australian
Shepherd #290. These dogs were last examined on 19-September-2023. Failure to have each dog examined at least
once every 12 months may result in delay of treatment and diagnosis for disease, illness, or injury. Correct by ensuring
that a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian is conducted not less
than once every 12 months.
To be corrected by: 27-November-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative and the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility’s Acquisition of Dogs on Hand (Form 7005) shows 42 adult dogs on hand. The inventory count obtained 
during inspection is 13 adult dogs. The facility representative states that they have not made changes to the 7005 form 
recently with recent dog dispositions. A correct inventory count is important to maintain for disease traceback, and in 
cases of theft or loss. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose each dog 
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of. Correct by maintaining current 
and accurate inventory on all dogs at the facility.  
To be corrected by: 18-November-2024 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Several primary enclosures housing 12 adult dogs have an excessive accumulation of hair and brown, dusty organic 
debris coating the wires on top of the enclosures. Two of the corner enclosures have a heavy buildup of cobwebs above 
them as well. Accumulation of dirt, hair, debris and cobwebs can serve as a source of disease hazards, which may cause 
injury or illness to the dogs. Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures be cleaned and sanitized at least once every 2 
weeks or as often as needed to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, or other disease hazards. 
To be corrected by: 18-November-2024 
3.13(a)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care states the attending veterinarian will complete a site visit every 6 months. The attending 
veterinarian has not been to the facility since 27-March-2024 and is now overdue for the site visit. Regularly scheduled 
site visits are essential in determining if all aspects of animal care (nutrition, health, environment, water, and air quality, 
etc.) are being provided to the dogs. The licensee must have regularly scheduled visits by the attending veterinarian to 
the facility where animals are kept, to assess and ensure the adequacy of veterinary care and other aspects of animal 
care and use. 
To be corrected by: 27-November-2024 
3.13(a)(2)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
Six adult dogs did not have an a complete physical examination from head to tail by the attending veterinarian done every 
12 months. The dogs not examined were Pomeranian #221, Pugs #165, #296, #282, Maltese #173 and Mini Australian 
Shepherd #290. These dogs were last examined on 19-September-2023. Failure to have each dog examined at least 
once every 12 months may result in delay of treatment and diagnosis for disease, illness, or injury. Correct by ensuring 
that a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian is conducted not less 
than once every 12 months. 
To be corrected by: 27-November-2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative and the licensee.
